title: How to become a… jockey
text:
People might imagine that winning the Grand National after 15 tries would top the list as being the best moment of my career, but a lot of jockeys have won that race.

Beating Sir Gordon Richards’ record total of winning horses in one season in 2002 – a record he held for 55 years – now that was the highlight of my professional life.

I remember when Wayne Rooney beat Sir Bobby Charlton’s all-time record at Old Trafford stadium in 2017. Bobby said he was proud to see it, but he was lying.

Not wanting to sound arrogant, but I hope I’m dead before all my records are broken.

Who do you think will win British Champions Day 2019?

Oisin Murphy will be the champion jockey this year.

Twenty years ago, the British Champions Day race was a really big deal, but horse racing has become more global and international events have taken over.

I’ve been really impressed with Oisin’s attitude and his respect for the race.

When did you first realise you wanted to be a jockey?

The first photo of me sat on a horse is from when I was just two years old.

My dad was a builder at the time and somehow ended up doing a job where he came away with a horse as payment. I have four sisters and one brother, none of whom have ever ridden horses – I’m not saying I believe in fate, but I have no idea why I’m the one in the family who ended up on our horse Miss Claire, as she was known.

The only time I feel like I am truly amazing is when I’m on a horse (Picture: Leo Mason/Popperfoto via Getty Images)

I have always loved horses. I used to sneak away from my mum when I was a child and she’d find me standing among them in the stables. They’re therapeutic animals and I get on better with them than I do with people, because they don’t answer back.

What qualifications do you need and how long does it take to get them?

It’s a bit embarrassing for me to admit, but I don’t have any specific qualifications, though I’ve never failed an exam. The man I was riding for said that going to school would interfere with my real education – horse racing – and so I left school at 15.

The good thing about horse racing nowadays is that the sport doesn’t discriminate against anyone – you can be any nationality, gender and age – and you don’t even need to have any equine experience to get started.

If you’re interested in becoming a jockey you would either go to the National Horseracing College (NHC) or the British Racing School, where you can obtain a level one or level two Diploma in racehorse care and get the relevant training, and then become an apprentice jockey or conditional jockey.

Regardless of your route to the job, you’ll need to apply for a jockey license.

What’s the biggest sacrifice you’ve made for your career?

My youngest sister was four years old when I left home at 15, so I didn’t get to see her grow up.

I’ve also broken pretty much every bone in my body, and used to eat once a day to keep my weight down, as well as travel 75,000 miles a year in a car to get to various races across the UK.

There have been personal sacrifices, but I’ve had the best life in the world.

I came out of retirement to take part in the Pat Smullen Champions Race for Cancer Trials Ireland, riding against eight other champions – and I managed to beat them all (Picture: Seb Daly/Sportsfile via Getty Images)

Favourite race you’ve taken part in?

My favourite race ever is actually the one I did three weeks ago.

I came out of retirement to take part in the Pat Smullen Champions Race for Cancer Trials Ireland, riding against eight other champions – and I managed to beat them all.

I loved that race for two reasons; firstly, it was held by a friend of ours, whose family member got diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and we raised over £2.5million for the charity.

Advertisement

On a more competitive note, I’ve known the other jockeys for a long time, and there’s a great sense of satisfaction in beating your mates, especially mates who are better than everyone else at what they do.

This was also the last race I’ll ever do, so they can’t get one back over me.

Why did the Grand National elude you when other races came so easily?

There are lots of jockeys who are better than me who have never won a Grand National, like John Francome and Peter Scudamore.

Sometimes the race just isn’t meant to be.

I won the Grand National on my 15th try in 2010, racing for JP McManus on a horse called Don’t Push It.

It was extra special because of my close relationship with JP, I raced for him for 12 years and he treated me like a son.

How hard it is for jockeys to keep their weight down?

I’ve ridden in more than 18,000 races, a distance that is equivalent to around 2.5 trips around the Earth, so I’ve always been physically fit. I also don’t smoke or drink.

To keep the weight down, I used to eat once a day. It was hard but also so boring because this daily meal generally consisted of healthy foods like fish. When I retired, I spent a year eating a cooked breakfast every morning.

I’d do it even when I wasn’t hungry, just because I could – eggs, bacon, mushrooms, the lot.

Advertisement

Is it hard to make money as a jockey?

Most jockeys get paid once a month by Weatherby’s Racing Bank, a dedicated bank for those in the industry.

Being a jockey isn’t as financially rewarding as football or golf, and many of the jockeys I competed against now have a more regular form of employment; for example, there are lads who rode at Cheltenham Festival who are now electricians.

The only time I feel like I am truly amazing is when I’m on a horse. It’s never been about the money.

When my monthly statement came, I wouldn’t even look at it – as long as I was winning, I knew I’d be OK financially.

AP took up golfing in the late 90s and got the chance to meet pro golfer Tiger Woods in 2010 (Picture: Patrick Bolger/Getty Images)

Any fun anecdotes?

The greatest moment of my career – that didn’t take part on a horse – was when I played golf with Tiger Woods in 2010.

I started playing golf in 1997, which is around the time he won his first Masters – he’s the reason I joined the sport.

I’ve also been lucky to spend some time in Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II’s company, on and off the track. She invited me for lunch at Windsor Castle once; I’m a catholic from Northern Ireland – if this was 30 years ago, that might have been frowned upon.

We bonded over our love of horses, she is a huge horse racing fan.

At Ascot, she asked me what I thought of her horse and the jockey riding it and while I won’t tell you what I said, I can tell you that she didn’t need any guidance from me. She knows her stuff.

Did the danger of the job ever outweigh the thrill?

The great thing about being a jockey is that you don’t become too wrapped up in yourself.

Because of the dangers of the sport you have a lot of respect for your colleagues. I have seen fatal injuries and fellow jockeys fall, knowing that they’ll never come back. I was also once so badly injured, I thought it was fatal – but now I’m retired, I miss the danger.

Like racing legend James Hunt said: ‘The closer you are to death, the more alive you feel’.

Advice to any aspiring jockeys?

Everyone has opinions, but statistics don’t lie.

Look at who is the best, learn from them, analyse their moves and copy them – to a point – then find your own edge.

Believe in yourself, but have the work ethic to back it up.

I’d say there’s a trick to winning, but all I could work out was about getting from A to B as quickly as possible.

That little fraction that makes the difference is instinctive, but the more you do it, the easier it becomes.

Sir AP McCoy will be co-presenting ITV Racing coverage of British Champions Day 2019.
